On april 24, 2013
[1368543]

You receive your new missile at the start of the level. If, for example, you complete a level on a shop and are down 1 missile, you still receive the option to buy a missile from the shop. However if you instead just go to play another level you'll find that you're already maxed out once you start playing.
On april 24, 2013
[1360724]

And once you have it, when you have all your missiles, it's worth to shoot at least one per level, because the next level you start will already start with all your missiles available. With that shot you can target multiple blocks so you're that much closer to the auto-javelins and to completing the level .

I am about to consider starting to plan a PID journey, but I had a question. At the moment, I have no (surface) engine or landing pod upgrades. Are these mandatory to land to reach the surface merchants to buy some of the PID pieces?
On april 27, 2013
[1360724]

You have the weakest surface engine and the shortest landing pods. I would strongly recommend you do some upgrading, otherwise with your current ones it's gonna be pretty difficult to land on some bigger planets (now you'll be able to land just fine on a couple of asteroids with PIDs and smaller planets).

Samosa for example is gonna be down right impossible with what you have. Douriv is also a pretty dense planet with lots of obstacles in the way. I can tell you that with 6 m landing pods (2 upgrades for you, first to 4m then to 6m) and with surface engine v3 - cheapest is close to Samosa - again 2 upgrades over your) I can land on any planet without any problem, includin Samosa. V2 will do just fine as well with a little practice, but it would be nice if if you had the 6m landing pods. 4m + v2 will probably be enough, but it would take some good skills and practice to land on bigger planets.

If you need to decide which one to upgrade first, I would recommend going one level for each (so not 2 engine upgrades and no landing pods upgrades) and in my case I consider the surface engine to be more valuable than the landing pods, but maybe others have other oppinions.

I have the 6m + v3 setup I mentioned and landing anywhere is a piece of cake. I only have one more upgrade for the landing pods (to 8m) and for the surface engine V4, but I'm only gathering for them for the sake of having them, not out of necesity .

On june 20, 2013
Launcelot

bully09 The surface engines that you can purchase, are upgrades to the original engine that you got ages ago for free. So you are currently on your 2nd upgrade, which is level 3. When you purchase the final upgrade, the 3rd upgrade that the cheapest costs 143,489 that will be level 4. Next question, yes that's right. Also, special pod extension is 6 meter long and the ultimate extension is 8 meter long. I feel like I can land on just about anything with my special extension, I assume with the ultimate you can do a 360, then a flip, a counter clockwise 90 with the upper leg pointing the sky and all of that without really looking.

On november 10, 2013
[1360724]

Yes, volt capsules are your friends in levels like that. That's where they really shine. Haven't used them much elsewhere... Also make sure you have an ice capsule, those will also keep the sentinels off your back and give the drones time to difuse as many as possible.

Even the quasar one is handy if there's a level with plenty of them and there are a lot in the center of the screen... Just don't use the fire one. Especially for FURI it makes the ball break an extra brick, going like a knife through butter, increasing the chances of hitting a sentinel.

Anyway, standard practice, always start a planet with all the capsules in the inventory .

On november 16, 2013
Launcelot

I strongly recommend you don't attempt to land there until you have the special pod extension and the 2nd surface engine. Anything less than that and you'll be hard pressed to find landing spots. Better wait until you're prepared and go there later, than go right now and collect a fraction of one of the wealthiest planets in the game. I did it with the 2nd surface engine like I recommend, but with the standard pod extension like yours and overall I must have collected about 80% of the planet's surface, wish I had waited a little longer. Cheapest special extension is a little too far but it's an investment that will pay off on demanding planets like Douriv. And don't forget the 2nd surface engine, that's not close either but Douriv's gravitational pull is no joke. I was able to choose between 2, maybe 3 landing spots before I ran out of fuel.. no time to scan the entire surface and then I had so little fuel left I had to make rough landings and hope my pods would come out in time, which they did most of the time.. I still regret the times I crashed though. I can't imagine doing it with the 1st surface engine. Good luck.

Before Twinoid, there was a referral system where if you refer someone to AlphaBounce and that person purchases , you gain a bonus amount equal to 20% percent of the amount of SHCs purchased. If multiple accounts were allowed, it would be possible for one person to effectively gain free SHCs for no effort. Now, you need a Twinoid account to play AB, and you are not allowed to have multiple Twinoid accounts because there are some Twinoid sites that offer Amazon gift cards as rewards.

Congrats! There are routes you can take to never run out of the only thing you're required to do is spend some time replaying the same levels. When the route is made of 300 sectors, most of which being abundant in , by the time you get back to start again you'll have a fresh batch of ready to be collected. And when you average 220 per sector, by the time you're back you'll have enough to purchase 600 so your net profit is 300 . Repeat and you have another 300 you can do this all day, get back to your cheap merchant purchase your free and go back to the same sectors. The second time will be even more profitable because you'll be visiting explored areas so you'll be avoiding unecessary sectors. The stronger your generator the higher you'll average.

So I completed my 115th cleanup and dropped 2 passengers off. Lucky me next cleanup is located on the inner side of the belt at the bottom, just 7 away from the Pofiak merchant. Retrofused myself and headed south, played a few rich sectors and got to the merchant.

Remaning before the purchase: 437
Available before the purchase: 102,546

Purchased : 940 (for 109 per unit)
Available after the purchase: 1,377

Couple days ago I had just completed my mining trip and I said if I were to purchase the from the Pofiak merchant I would've had 1,396 (if I could teleport to his shop straight away) but I wanted to wait until I got a cleanup nearby. Since then I've completed 1 cleanup, I had to play all 36 sectors of it, plus the sectors I played to get there (just outside the belt west of the anti-radar asteroid) and then the sectors from the origin to the Pofiak merchant where I'm now. After carefully planning my route, picking up all the rich sectors, plus the 2 passengers from Balixt, I've managed to spend just 18 for all of that so after the purchase I've got 1,377 and I'm ready to head south-east for my next cleanup.

So I just wanted to say this... if you focus on purchasing and nothing else, game will become much more amusing, distance will mean nothing, you'll say I wanna be there and you will be there. But for it to work, you need to have some stuff, like a very good generator.. it won't work with level 4 or 5 it will hurt your average per sector and you need to make sure you won't lose every once in a while so you need to have some stuff to help you out. That means, you won't be able to take advantage of the method until you've spent a lot of to purchase all that stuff first. Besides you need the PID's anyway otherwise you'll never complete the game, obviously.

So after you've done all that you can focus on purchasing and literally free yourself from having to wait for your . Ever since I've been doing this I've never worried about running out of and going to places has never been easier. Oh and you also need to have about 300 to begin with, either via the interstellar bank or about 32k. With that you can start your mining trip right away, then go to the Pofiak merchant and purchase 600 because you'll be making 2 for every you use (need to average 218 per sector).

I have already shared my mining route coordinates. FURI players need more because you won't be able to teleport back to origin after your trip, but the way back is still rich in so I don't think your average will be affected.. it will just take you more time. My mining coordinates do not include the way back for FURI so when you're done mining, you need to plan out your return.

On may 12, 2014
Launcelot

Considering you played it with no more than 5 drones and a furi envelope, it had to be pretty tough, I'd probably beat head too. But here's what happens here...

Like I've said before and I truly believe that, for most levels the asphalt ball with the twinner is better than the srx missiles and mines, and even the larger envelope too, at least that's the impression I get from watching videos. You clear the levels faster and with less drama. But there are some cases where it's more important to be able to hold the ball a little longer even if you don't hit anything, than go on a rampage against the bricks. This is one of these cases that favors escorp.

Here the obvious way out is allow your drones to come out and hopefully dismantle the paralyzing sentinels at the bottom. If you had 10 drones, you wouldn't worry about the lure sentinels, since in my experience 7-8 of them only trap maybe 4-5 of your drones, leaving the remaining 5-6 to work their way through the rest of the sentinels. It's not like you have a million sentinels either, I'd say you have an average number for a level of this difficulty. The larger the envelope, the longer you can hold the ball in that little space you have at the bottom, allowing your drones to not only clear a good chunk of the paralyzing sentinels but probably a kashuat or two as well. Meanwhile you focus on hitting either one of the dragon bricks, that will open up the way when you're ready to work on the upper part of the map, which will be as soon as your drones clear the sentinels, or a good chunk of them.

The guardians at the bottom aren't a problem anymore as the paralyzing sentinels are out of the way and you can safely take them out. If your ball is going too fast by now, you can take a shot at killing the molecule generators and if you hit a molecule in the process, you were going to lose the ball anyway because it was going too fast already so no harm is done. Chances are you have already got rid of a couple lure sentinels, possibly freeing up another drone or two.

You should be on your way to get rid of all paralyzing and kashuat sentinels by now, with only the molecules and maybe a generator standing in the way, along with the upper guardians. Again, take another shot against the generators and a few molecules if your ball is going too fast, otherwise focus on killing the upper guardians avoiding the molecules. As soon as they're out, you can fire a missile to get rid of the generators if they're still around and you're probably gonna take out a bunch of molecules too.

That's how I'd play this level. I give it a couple lives, maybe 3. Really 10 drones and a larger envelope would make the world of difference here. I've played similar levels.

drakh

I buy upgrades only when my wandering brings me close enough to one of the cheapest merchant that sells them. I already know where I'll buy them, when is unknown though .
As for , I don't need them. I prefer to keep accumulating just for the sake of it. 3 (just recently 4) per day are enough for me. I might get some from FURI rebels or from alien transportations from time to time when exploring a planet or when I feel like bringing someone on board for a while.
If I played a lot using earned via I'd just lose a goal in the game, which would then become less interesting. By the same token, if I rushed to reach Terre and completed my profile I'd have had to search once more another goal. Or maybe I'd have stopped to play for lack of interest.
Keeping this slow pace allows me to spend few relaxing minutes per day on this website for years to come (until MT decides to close it).

No bug here
Going into nightmare mode resets your exploration, so you went back to the bottom (as if you were a completely new player)

The maximum security rankings are a separate thing that only shows players who are in nightmare mode. You might get into the top 100 in that ranking, but that only means you're above ~35 other people

Welcome back Pie!

On march 25, 2015
[1360724]
iGenesis...
How long does the BalmanchChagarina corridor take for non-payers to get through? I imagine around 2-4 months? Can't wait to finish this tedious game...

Use the map to calculate stuff like this. Click on Balmanch, shift+click on Chagarina (to set Beacon 1 and 2), set your engine and radar values, and depending on whether you explored some of the levels or not, it will give you the best and worst case scenarios (if all levels are explored and you can use the engine at its full potential or if you've never been there and you're limited by radar).

In your case it should take between 160 and 230 levels (presuming you go in a straight line and you don't die and you go as far as possible with each . Divide that by 4 (because you have 4 per day) and you see that it will take you between 40 and 58 days .

On august 4, 2015
Launcelot

I think you shouldn't bother before getting v6 generator, ideally v7, but since you need to travel all the way to Terre for it, it might be a good idea to load up first.

The other thing you need is a decent number of upgrades because you're gonna have to play a few challenging levels, and since you want your route to be as efficient as possible, losing is not an option. So you need to have 3 or 4 lives, a lot of drones with the perforation upgrade, lots of MAS-Z or AR-SRX missiles, Delta or Asphalt ball and perpetual synthesis motor is good to have as well. Oh and you need of course! At least 300 to get you started. They won't be enough to complete his entire route but you don't need to, just make sure you keep enough for your return. By the time you've ran out, you'll have enough to purchase 600+ and you can go back for another round. I was happy with the merchant over at Pofiak but you can use other cheap merchants if you want.

I came up with the idea of unlimited after exploring my last planet, Folket. I used the wormhole and found myself surrounded by green and blue sectors I couldn't ignore. So I started making detours until I finally got to Folket. That's when I realized I had enough to purchase twice the I had spent and since I had already played 200 sectors, I could come back for more. So I did Folket, retrofused myself, went to Pofiak and returned to the wormhole. That's when I started mapping my route, that originally didn't have the bottom part since I didn't need it the first time I went to Folket, and I added it the second time around when I headed "south".

I haven't updated it since, it's still the same as shown on abmap, but when I started my latest journey (to the edge of the universe) I went through Samosa and saved my path on minemap. Now I need to update my route and add this part, that will go all the way to Samosa and beyond.

So anyway, I got into these routes after completing my profile (Folket was last) but you don't have to go nearly this far. Just make sure you have the upgrades with v6 generator as I mentioned earlier (v7 is definitely more efficient, but v6 will do), and take the route. When you have enough , take the trip to Terre.

bubuletz

Use the map to calculate stuff like this. Click on Balmanch, shift+click on Chagarina (to set Beacon 1 and 2), set your engine and radar values, and depending on whether you explored some of the levels or not, it will give you the best and worst case scenarios (if all levels are explored and you can use the engine at its full potential or if you've never been there and you're limited by radar).

In your case it should take between 160 and 230 levels (presuming you go in a straight line and you don't die and you go as far as possible with each . Divide that by 4 (because you have 4 per day) and you see that it will take you between 40 and 58 days .

Actually it took far longer than that. The levels in that area aren't exactly easy and I can't always progress 16 sectors per day. There are objects to collect and rich sectors that you just don't want to miss.

I lost about two weeks because I didn't carry a capsule to Volcer. One of the levels with a map piece cannot be beaten without capsules or missiles. I'd like to see a video if anyone can do it.

Launcelot

Why, thank you

All I did was study the wiki and the maps. Had my alien transportations and those I was supposed to denounce listed in a text file, to avoid visiting the same sectors and tried to plan my trips out in a way to save . For example I had an alien waiting for a ride, but I wouldn't pick 'em up unless I had a cleanup mission that would bring me 5 sectors away and the next cleanup would be on my way, including the alien's destination. Of course retrofusor made things a lot easier, but it was always a matter of spent vs earned. I was patient, didn't rush, after all AB is such a big game you can literally take your time (as in played sectors) and do it the right way. Everything I did was entirely based on saving , so if there is one thing I could say is take your time to do your missions, but from what I can tell you're already doing this. I'm sure those who study these things are all doing the best they can.

Also, pick up a few more upgrades like another 5 drones, the missile regenerator thingy, delta ball, 2nd radar and 6th generator, and take a few routes. Just make sure they are FURI friendly. I didn't do this until after I had already completed my profile. In fact the whole idea came to me while I was on my way to Folket, the last thing on my profile. But there's no need to wait this long, just need to beef yourself up to make sure you won't lose often and that's it. No need to wait for .

As for my 4th radar, that was luck. I just happened to get into an anti-radar asteroid before picking up ambro-x, without knowing the merchant would actually upgrade my radar for 60 .

How about an accomplishment and a rant?

So few levels earlier I beat my probably toughest level yet, on my gazillionth attempt. There was such a ridiculous amount of creation molecules that the only way out was to avoid hitting them at all costs. On top of that, there was also a decent number of flash and reverting molecules that you just couldn't avoid, so in a matter of seconds you would lose control of the ball, and every single time it would end up hitting a creation molecule you've been trying to hard to avoid. Upon hitting that, it would naturally start dumping bricks making the ball even harder to control, and before you had time to curse another 15 creation molecules would come out to cause serious carnage. So naturally you would resort to blowing the shit out, right? But you couldn't, because of 4 guardian bricks, 2 of which protected by a fucking steel brick and another 2 halfway across the screen. Yeah, kindly keep away from missiles, thank you.

Well, eventually I did manage to avoid hitting the creation molecules, while trying to hold on until the javelin kicked in. But it was extremely hard especially after releasing the flash and reverting molecules, and I was lucky the ball didn't hit the other molecules in the process. That happened once in I dunno how many attempts. There weren't many gray bricks to destroy (lots of thick brown bricks instead - as always) that's why relying on the javelin was in fact a viable solution, but keeping control of the ball was like trying to help an ant light a cigarette. Of course to take out the last gray bricks you would have to release a few creation molecules, but you wouldn't care if you used javelin so.. yeah, that was it.

On may 6, 2016
Launcelot

It gets insanely harder after 10k sectors. I have noticed speed has inceased 3 times since getting beyond Terre. The first increase was a little after Terre, second was about halfway through my journey and the third was actually about 100 sectors before my current position. Right now it takes about 20 seconds before the ball gets way too fast to control, about as fast as keeping it for 2 minutes in levels before Terre. On top of that you also get a ridiculously large number of very thick brown bricks that you have to take out before auto-javelin even kicks in, lots of death bricks and molecules and sometimes you'll get guardian bricks too, so your missiles won't help much there. And you have to save your missiles when you can, rocket barrage is not recommended.

One other thing I have noticed though, is that my skills have improved considerably since taking this journey. I have managed to adapt pretty well, following new strategies (you really need strategies to survive out here remember it gets insanely fast after 20 seconds) and thanks to that I can win at least 2/3 , often 3/3.

I don't leave skulls behind btw. In fact I don't have a single skull in the entire game.
On may 6, 2016
Launcelot

Forgot to say you don't get lots of power-ups either, except for M which is basically useless, if not making it even worse. For example N, E and L are rare, and forget about K, O and Q, those are like one in a million. Occasionally you do get free balls (the ones inside a brick) but many times they are positioned next to a death brick or a regeneration molecule that you don't want to hit, so it gets a little more complicated. I guess you're pretty much on your own.

On october 15, 2016
Launcelot

Here's something interesting I found out that I'd like to share. Few days ago I was playing a level, had a couple bricks left and on my last extra life I launched a missile like half a second before hitting a death brick. Got game over no surprise there, but l always knew that once a death brick ate your ball, there was no way out. In fact even if you had cleared the level and your ball somehow hit one on the way, mission ok would change to game over. I've had this happen a million times. This here was the first time I hit a death brick before clearing the level, so it turns out there IS a way out after game over and I have to assume that getting shot by a Guardian or a Kashuat wouldn't make a difference. So game over changed to mission ok as soon as my missile cleared those last few bricks. Pretty sweet.

On march 26, 2017
N_Faker

As far as I know it is the most efficient route.
It intersects with a shop which sells SHC for 110, which will matter a lot if you plan to mine for a long time.

Most all levels on the route are relatively easy.
On march 26, 2017
N_Faker

For a V6 with the current data, with the intention to gain the most minerals and disregarding level difficulty.

The complete route would take 321 SHC.
187 of which would have to be played and 134 which would be suicides after gathering the minerals.

Total minerals collected would be 73385 with an average of 228,61 min/SHC
Main route minerals account for 37522(200,65min/SHC)
Suicide minerals account for 35863(267,63min/SHC)

Total yield per trip would be 38075 minerals, if you subtract the used SHC with a value of 110.

The average can of course be greatly improved by removing low mineral yield suicide moves and changing the main route.

On march 11, 2018
Launcelot

Here's something I found out today... You don't always lose if (on your last life) you hit a death brick while taking out the last brick. This is how it works; it basically depends on when you actually hit it. If you hit it after having cleared the level, which is how it usually happens, like you hit the last brick and the ball bounces off and hits the death brick, "mission ok" turns into "game over" and you lose...

Today I found out if you hit that death brick but just before hitting it you manage to fire a missile, in a way that you clear the level afterwards, "game over" turns into "mission ok". Up until now I thought this could only happen after losing the ball, like missing it, while firing a missile and clearing the level. But I thought once you hit a death brick you were done, regardless how you cleared the level. Turns out it behaves the same way, and I bet guardians and kashuats should be no exception. So there, in your face, skull.
On march 11, 2018

Here's something I found out today... You don't always lose if (on your last life) you hit a death brick while taking out the last brick. This is how it works; it basically depends on when you actually hit it. If you hit it after having cleared the level, which is how it usually happens, like you hit the last brick and the ball bounces off and hits the death brick, "mission ok" turns into "game over" and you lose...

Today I found out if you hit that death brick but just before hitting it you manage to fire a missile, in a way that you clear the level afterwards, "game over" turns into "mission ok". Up until now I thought this could only happen after losing the ball, like missing it, while firing a missile and clearing the level. Yes, I remember something similar. I think it's coded so that whichever state comes last decides the outcome during that small 2 second or so gap after triggering end of level. So I guess it can go both ways with a death brick.
On march 29, 2018
Launcelot

That makes sense.

Meanwhile I've been thinking about firing that thing I've locked up for years. This journey has been a blast, tested my skills against some incredibly difficult levels - I still haven't left one single skull behind btw - had to adapt to clearing levels in just a little over a minute as that's more or less the time I had before the ball went too fast to control - that is in fact about 25 seconds per ball - but I've missed exploring planets, landing, collecting minerals to trade for (I have 60k but last merchant I ran into was several thousands of sectors away).

Aside from missing all that, levels out here are starting to annoy me not because of their increased difficulty, but there seems to be a pattern in their design, making them all the more similar, and therefore boring. 3 out of 10 levels are Grimorn-ish, usually with powerups but there's often little you can do when the ball goes berzerk in 30 seconds - I have actually been forced to use missiles and that says something - 6 out of 10 feature a very thick layer of beefed up brown bricks at the bottom, very close to the paddle, a bunch of death bricks here and there and all the bricks you need to hit are placed at the top and as you know auto javelin won't kick in until you hit your first brick. Occasionally there are also guardians (a real nightmare on such levels) and molecules, and less often dragon, destruction, regeneration, factory and steel bricks, one-way bricks (not always helpful considering there are often death bricks at the top), molecule generators and extra balls. I rarely see missile bricks, orbital nuts and kashuats, and there are bricks I haven't seen for a very long time like extra life bricks, jumper bricks, inversion, parasite, reducines, paralyzers, gluantes and lure sentinels, those are like gone. And I won't mention mission bricks obviously, there is none left (missed that too btw). And the remaining 10% are basically molecule levels, with like 30 molecules covering the entire level, among that brown/death brick pattern with all or most normal bricks at the very top.

I wanted a challenge and got it, enjoyed it. Gameplay is hot and thrilling as hell. But maybe it's time to make that thing count. I'm still debating...

Here is another level I beat earlier. Notice the same pattern, except we now have molecules in place of kashuats, we got no death bricks and we got more steel bricks near the bottom. Granted they can both be a pita when combined with repulsion molecules, just imagine 6 or 7 guardians on a level like this. Fortunately though, when these show up, there will be something to compensate your missile problem, like a normal brick near the bottom, so you can enable auto J. Few times that I didn't have that either, the guardians were within my reach, more or less, so what I did was sacrifice a couple lives to get rid of them, and then blew the whole place up.

9. Venture to Terre and explore it.
10. Return to the origin with my new upgrades. Roll a d100 dice to decide whether I will complete 200 missions, retire, or start over again in Nightmare Mode.With the previous semester being over, I finally had the time to create a detailed plan based off this general one on my "Alphabounce Plan" Excel spreadsheet for everything leading up until Terre. As a fun fact, my spreadsheet consists of my entire Alphabounce history leading back to my first Karbonite Tablet. The columns on my spreadsheet are "Destination", "Coordinates", "Distance from Last Point", "Minimum Turns from Last Point", and "Status". Funny how being bored out of your mind doing 56 Cleanup missions in a row leads one to take the time to create such a spreadsheet. I'm actually going to do step 6 before I complete 100 Cleanup missions because I want to actually make use of the Ultimate pod extension after I get it. Additionally, I'm going to force myself to do LoyeH's mineral route many times before completing 100 Cleanup missions because I want to have the ability to finish the game just in case Alphabounce ends at the time when Flash does.

Excluding detours and the trip to Terre, after I complete 100 Cleanup missions I'll have a minimum of 1672 plays left until I finish the game.
